children.name: Adleman 1
Theorem. Adleman 1978 BPP ⊆ P/poly
keywords: Theorem. Adleman 1978 BPP ⊆ P/poly

children.name: BPP definition
keywords: BPP definition

children.name: P/poly = a polynomial time algorithm, which is allowed an advice string for every input length.
keywords: P/poly = a polynomial time algorithm, which is allowed an advice string for every input length.

children.name: equivalent to (nonuniform) circuits of polynomial size
keywords: equivalent to (nonuniform) circuits of polynomial size

children.name: In a BPP algorithm, we can make the probability of error exponentially small, while preserving polynomial running time (and coin tosses).
keywords: In a BPP algorithm, we can make the probability of error exponentially small, while preserving polynomial running time (and coin tosses).

children.name: For small enough error probability, there will be a sequence of coin tosses which gives a right answer of all inputs of length n.
keywords: For small enough error probability, there will be a sequence of coin tosses which gives a right answer of all inputs of length n.

keywords: advice string

Adleman 3

children.name: Conclusion. There is a constant c such for every n, there exists a sequence of cn coin tosses which gives a correct answer for all inputs of length n, under the algorithm “run the orignal algorithm cn times, and take a majority vote”.
keywords: Conclusion. There is a constant c such for every n, there exists a sequence of cn coin tosses which gives a correct answer for all inputs of length n, under the algorithm “run the orignal algorithm cn times, and take a majority vote”.

children.name: BPP = P
Theorem. If a pseudo-random generator G exists, then BPP = P.
keywords: Theorem. If a pseudo-random generator G exists, then BPP = P.

keywords: with the following properties

children.name: Proof. Consider a language L ∈ BPP, as witnessed by a machine M such that: - the running time is a polynomial p(n) - inputs w ∈ L accepted with probability > 0.7 - inputs w ∉ L are accepted with probability < 0.3
keywords: Proof. Consider a language L ∈ BPP, as witnessed by a machine M such that: - the running time is a polynomial p(n) - inputs w ∈ L accepted with probability > 0.7 - inputs w ∉ L are accepted with probability < 0.3

children.name: Polynomial time algorithm for L: Given an input w of length n, enumerate through all seeds s of length log(p(n)), and check which ones satisfy
keywords: Polynomial time algorithm for L: Given an input w of length n, enumerate through all seeds s of length log(p(n)), and check which ones satisfy

children.name: (*) M accepts w using random bits G(s)
keywords: (*) M accepts w using random bits G(s)

children.name: Claim. For large enough n: - if w ∈ L, then > 0.6 of seeds will satisfy (*) - if w ∉ L, then < 0.4 of seeds will satisfy (*)
keywords: Claim. For large enough n: - if w ∈ L, then > 0.6 of seeds will satisfy (*) - if w ∉ L, then < 0.4 of seeds will satisfy (*)

children.name: Derandomisation
Given a graph, find a cut of maximal size?
keywords: Given a graph, find a cut of maximal size?
A cut of size k is a partition of vertices into two parts, such that there are exactly k edges between the parts

children.name: The following problem is NP-complete: given a graph and k, decide is there a cut of size ≥ k.
keywords: The following problem is NP-complete: given a graph and k, decide is there a cut of size ≥ k.

children.name: Randomised approximation algorithm
keywords: Randomised approximation algorithm
returned value is at most 2 times worse

children.name: Choose the partition randomly For each vertex, independently flip a coin to decide which part of the partition contains it.
keywords: Choose the partition randomly For each vertex, independently flip a coin to decide which part of the partition contains it.

children.name: With probability 1/2, an edge is counted to the size of the cut. Hence, the expected value of “size of the cut” is 1/2 over the number of edges.
keywords: With probability 1/2, an edge is counted to the size of the cut. Hence, the expected value of “size of the cut” is 1/2 over the number of edges.

children.name: exptected size
What is the probability of getting a cut of size ≥ m?
keywords: What is the probability of getting a cut of size ≥ m?
We care about m =expected size, which is half of the edges

keywords: expected size

children.name: Two ways of derandomising
We derandomise this algorithm, getting a deterministic polynomial time algorithm, which always produces a partition that cuts ≥ half the edges.
keywords: We derandomise this algorithm, getting a deterministic polynomial time algorithm, which always produces a partition that cuts ≥ half the edges.

children.name: Result: a deterministic, polynomial time, approximation algorithm for max-cut, with approximation factor 2
keywords: Result: a deterministic, polynomial time, approximation algorithm for max-cut, with approximation factor 2
